item.title: How to make NATO great again
item.description: Burden sharing can take many shapes, and benefit both domestic industry and allied economies.

item.title: RFK Jr.’s war on vaccines is coming for the elderly
item.description: The miseries of aging are more linked to late-life infections than was previously understood.

item.title: What it’s like to watch a dictatorship strangle your home country
item.description: This is not a time for optimism about Cuba — not yet. But I hope soon.

item.title: Buyer’s remorse in Asia
item.description: Trade deals risk unraveling after the Supreme Court’s tariff decision.

item.title: So much winning. But are we?
item.description: A show by the Washington Post Opinions. Stay tuned.

item.title: Banning stock trading for lawmakers is popular but unworkable
item.description: Requiring advance warning before buying and selling securities would be an easy and effective fix.

item.title: AI is coming. Is there enough power to run it?
item.description: We hear a lot about what artificial intelligence can do. We hear a lot less about what it takes to run it. The explosion of AI depends on massive data centers — and massive amounts of energy. Rep. Jake Auchincloss (D-Mass.) joins host Megan McArdle to discuss how his views on AI have evolved, and to explore how his state — and the nation — can meet the energy and infrastructure demands of the AI boom.

item.title: Tariff refunds are the only way
item.description: The government can do this the easy way or the hard way, but the stolen money needs to be returned.

item.title: To ‘supercharge’ defense, use extra funding outside the Pentagon
item.description: Readers on defense spending, public golf in D.C., home rule and more.

item.title: Cartoon by Lisa Benson
item.description: Lisa Benson cartoon on Trump, tariffs refunds and American consumers.

item.title: The Post prevailed in court. Yet the damage is done.
item.description: “First Amendment rights have been restrained”

item.title: ‘People Power’ is not what ends dictatorships
item.description: The Philippines’ uprising 40 years ago has been romanticized. But Tiananmen Square is a better guide.

item.title: Don’t save Social Security
item.description: Trying to fix the retirement program is infeasible. Better to find new ways of achieving its goals.

item.title: What the escape of at least 15,000 detainees means for ISIS
item.description: The escapees fleeing al-Hol could create the next generation of Islamic State fighters.

item.title: How Trump raced past the Supreme Court
item.description: The justices took months to reject illegal tariffs. Trump took hours to sidestep their ruling.

item.title: ‘Trump really ruins a feel-good moment’: 10 writers on the State of the Union
item.description: They offered live commentary on the address starting at 8:45 p.m. Tuesday.

item.title: Trump tries to rewrite the history of trade
item.description: The administration misinterprets a Nixon-era law in its bid to reimpose tariffs struck down by the Supreme Court.

item.title: The military caused the DCA crash. Now it’s trying to kill key fixes.
item.description: The Pentagon plays last-minute games to torpedo a bipartisan Senate deal.

item.title: Roundup needs legal protections. This is the wrong way to do it.
item.description: Glyphosate’s link to cancer has long been tenuous at best.

item.description: Edward J. Markey on self-driving vehicles, parents on snow days and more
